name: 1607_A. Linear Keyboard
description:
You are given a keyboard that consists of 26 keys. The keys are arranged sequentially in one row in a certain order. Each key corresponds to a unique lowercase Latin letter.

You have to type the word s on this keyboard. It also consists only of lowercase Latin letters.

To type a word, you need to type all its letters consecutively one by one. To type each letter you must position your hand exactly over the corresponding key and press it.

Moving the hand between the keys takes time which is equal to the absolute value of the difference between positions of these keys (the keys are numbered from left to right). No time is spent on pressing the keys and on placing your hand over the first letter of the word.

For example, consider a keyboard where the letters from 'a' to 'z' are arranged in consecutive alphabetical order. The letters 'h', 'e', 'l' and 'o' then are on the positions 8, 5, 12 and 15, respectively. Therefore, it will take |5 - 8| + |12 - 5| + |12 - 12| + |15 - 12| = 13 units of time to type the word "hello". 

Determine how long it will take to print the word s.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

The first line of a description contains a keyboard — a string of length 26, which consists only of lowercase Latin letters. Each of the letters from 'a' to 'z' appears exactly once on the keyboard.

The second line of the description contains the word s. The word has a length from 1 to 50 letters inclusive and consists of lowercase Latin letters.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case is the minimal time it takes to type the word s on the given keyboard.

Example

Input


5
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
hello
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
i
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
codeforces
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
qqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqq
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
abacaba


Output


13
0
68
0
74

prompt:
You are given a keyboard that consists of 26 keys. The keys are arranged sequentially in one row in a certain order. Each key corresponds to a unique lowercase Latin letter.

You have to type the word s on this keyboard. It also consists only of lowercase Latin letters.

To produce a word, you must write each letter consecutively, one after another. To type each letter you must position your hand exactly over the corresponding key and press it.

Moving the hand between the keys takes time which is equal to the absolute value of the difference between positions of these keys (the keys are numbered from left to right). No time is spent on pressing the keys and on placing your hand over the first letter of the word.

For example, consider a keyboard where the letters from 'a' to 'z' are arranged in consecutive alphabetical order. The letters 'h', 'e', 'l' and 'o' then are on the positions 8, 5, 12 and 15, respectively. Therefore, it will take |5 - 8| + |12 - 5| + |12 - 12| + |15 - 12| = 13 units of time to type the word "hello". 

Determine how long it will take to print the word s. The word s can have a maximum length of 10^5 characters. Assume each position on the keyboard is distinct and mapped to a single, specific letter. You are required to ensure optimal performance given the large possible length of the input word.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

The first line of a description contains a keyboard — a string of length 26, which consists only of lowercase Latin letters. Each of the letters from 'a' to 'z' appears exactly once on the keyboard.

The second line of the description contains the word s. The word has a length from 1 to 50 letters inclusive and consists of lowercase Latin letters.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case is the minimal time it takes to type the word s on the given keyboard.

Example

Input


5
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
hello
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
i
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
codeforces
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
qqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqq
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
abacaba


Output


13
0
68
0
74

You are given a keyboard that consists of 26 keys. The keys are arranged sequentially in one row in a certain order. Each key corresponds to a unique lowercase Latin letter.

You have to type the word s on this keyboard. It also consists only of lowercase Latin letters.

To produce a word, you must write each letter consecutively, one after another. To type each letter you must position your hand exactly over the corresponding key and press it.

Moving the hand between the keys takes time which is equal to the absolute value of the difference between positions of these keys (the keys are numbered from left to right). No time is spent on pressing the keys and on placing your hand over the first letter of the word.

For example, consider a keyboard where the letters from 'a' to 'z' are arranged in consecutive alphabetical order. The letters 'h', 'e', 'l' and 'o' then are on the positions 8, 5, 12 and 15, respectively. Therefore, it will take |5 - 8| + |12 - 5| + |12 - 12| + |15 - 12| = 13 units of time to type the word "hello". 

Determine how long it will take to print the word s. The word s can have a maximum length of 10^5 characters. Assume each position on the keyboard is distinct and mapped to a single, specific letter. You are required to ensure optimal performance given the large possible length of the input word.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

The first line of a description contains a keyboard — a string of length 26, which consists only of lowercase Latin letters. Each of the letters from 'a' to 'z' appears exactly once on the keyboard.

The second line of the description contains the word s. The word has a length from 1 to 50 letters inclusive and consists of lowercase Latin letters.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case is the minimal time it takes to type the word s on the given keyboard.

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.

Write a main() function and use input() function to read input from stdin

from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    """
    Calculate the time required to type a given word on a specific keyboard layout.

    Args:
        keyboard (str): A string representing the keyboard layout where each character is a unique lowercase Latin letter.
        word (str): The word to be typed, consisting of lowercase Latin letters.

    Returns:
        int: The total time required to type the word.
    """
    # Create a dictionary to map each key to its position on the keyboard
    key_positions = {}
    for index, key in enumerate(keyboard):
        key_positions[key] = index

    # Initialize the total time and the position of the previous key
    total_time = 0
    prev_position = 0

    # Calculate the time for each letter in the word
    for letter in word:
        current_position = key_positions[letter]
        total_time += abs(current_position - prev_position)
        prev_position = current_position

    return total_time

# Example usage
if __name__ == "__main__":
    import sys
    keyboard = sys.argv[1]
    word = sys.argv[2]
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    """
    Calculate the typing time based on the positions of the letters on the keyboard.

    Args:
        keyboard (str): A string representing the keyboard layout where each character is a unique lowercase Latin letter.
        word (str): The word to be typed, consisting of lowercase Latin letters.

    Returns:
        int: The total typing time in units.
    """
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {}
    for index, letter in enumerate(keyboard):
        keyboard_positions[letter] = index

    # Initialize the typing time
    typing_time = 0

    # Calculate the typing time for the word
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        prev_letter = word[i - 1]
        curr_letter = word[i]
        prev_pos = keyboard_positions[prev_letter]
        curr_pos = keyboard_positions[curr_letter]
        typing_time += abs(prev_pos - curr_pos)

    return typing_time

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(input().strip())

for _ in range(t):
    # Read the keyboard layout
    keyboard = input().strip()
    # Read the word to be typed
    word = input().strip()
    # Calculate and print the typing time
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    """
    Calculate the time required to type a given word on a specific keyboard layout.

    Args:
        keyboard (str): A string representing the keyboard layout where each character is a unique lowercase Latin letter.
        word (str): The word to be typed, consisting of lowercase Latin letters.

    Returns:
        int: The total time required to type the word.
    """
    # Create a dictionary to map each key to its position on the keyboard
    key_positions = {}
    for index, key in enumerate(keyboard):
        key_positions[key] = index

    # Initialize the total time to 0
    total_time = 0

    # Calculate the typing time for the word
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        current_key = word[i]
        previous_key = word[i - 1]
        current_position = key_positions[current_key]
        previous_position = key_positions[previous_key]
        # Add the absolute difference between the positions of the current and previous keys
        total_time += abs(current_position - previous_position)

    return total_time

# Read the number of test cases from stdin
import sys

t = int(sys.stdin.readline().strip())

for _ in range(t):
    # Read the keyboard layout and word for each test case
    keyboard = sys.stdin.readline().strip()
    word = sys.stdin.readline().strip()
    # Calculate and print the typing time for each word
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    """
    Calculate the time required to type a given word on a specific keyboard layout.
    
    Args:
        keyboard (str): A string representing the keyboard layout where each character is a unique lowercase Latin letter.
        word (str): The word to be typed, consisting of lowercase Latin letters.
        
    Returns:
        int: The total time required to type the word.
    """
    # Create a dictionary to map each key to its position on the keyboard
    key_positions = {}
    for index, key in enumerate(keyboard):
        key_positions[key] = index
    
    # Initialize the total time to 0
    total_time = 0
    
    # Calculate the time for each consecutive letter in the word
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        current_key_pos = key_positions[word[i]]
        previous_key_pos = key_positions[word[i - 1]]
        total_time += abs(current_key_pos - previous_key_pos)
    
    return total_time

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(input().strip())

for _ in range(t):
    # Read the keyboard layout
    keyboard = input().strip()
    # Read the word to be typed
    word = input().strip()
    # Calculate and print the typing time
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    """
    Calculate the typing time for a given word on a specific keyboard layout.

    Args:
        keyboard (str): A string representing the keyboard layout where each character is a key.
        word (str): The word to be typed.

    Returns:
        int: The total typing time for the word.
    """
    # Create a dictionary to map each key to its position on the keyboard
    key_positions = {}
    for index, key in enumerate(keyboard):
        key_positions[key] = index

    # Initialize the total typing time
    total_time = 0

    # Calculate the typing time for each letter in the word
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        prev_key = word[i - 1]
        current_key = word[i]
        total_time += abs(key_positions[prev_key] - key_positions[current_key])

    return total_time

# Example usage
if __name__ == "__main__":
    keyboard = input()
    word = input()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    """
    Calculate the typing time based on the positions of the keys on the keyboard.

    Args:
        keyboard (str): A string representing the keyboard layout where each character is a unique lowercase Latin letter.
        word (str): The word to be typed.

    Returns:
        int: The total typing time in units.
    """
    # Create a dictionary to map each key to its position
    key_positions = {}
    for index, key in enumerate(keyboard):
        key_positions[key] = index

    # Initialize the total typing time
    total_time = 0

    # Calculate the typing time for each letter in the word
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        current_key = word[i]
        previous_key = word[i - 1]
        current_pos = key_positions[current_key]
        previous_pos = key_positions[previous_key]
        total_time += abs(current_pos - previous_pos)

    return total_time

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(input())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    keyboard = input()
    word = input()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    position_map = {}
    for index, letter in enumerate(keyboard):
        position_map[letter] = index
    
    # Initialize the typing time
    typing_time = 0
    
    # Calculate the typing time for the word
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        current_pos = position_map[word[i]]
        previous_pos = position_map[word[i - 1]]
        typing_time += abs(current_pos - previous_pos)
    
    return typing_time

# Read the number of test cases

    keyboard = input()
    word = input()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)

## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to store the position of each key on the keyboard
    key_positions = {}
    
    # Populate the dictionary with positions of each key
    for index, key in enumerate(keyboard):
        key_positions[key] = index
    
    # Initialize the total typing time
    total_time = 0
    
    # Calculate the typing time for the word
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        current_key = word[i]
        previous_key = word[i - 1]
        current_pos = key_positions[current_key]
        previous_pos = key_positions[previous_key]
        total_time += abs(current_pos - previous_pos)

from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    """
    Calculate the time required to type a given word on a custom keyboard layout.

    Args:
        keyboard (str): A string representing the keyboard layout where each character is a unique lowercase Latin letter.
        word (str): The word to be typed, consisting of lowercase Latin letters.

    Returns:
        int: The total time required to type the word.
    """
    # Create a dictionary to map each key to its position on the keyboard
    key_positions = {}
    for index, key in enumerate(keyboard):
        key_positions[key] = index

    # Initialize the total time to 0
    total_time = 0

    # Calculate the time to type each letter in the word
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        current_key = word[i]
        previous_key = word[i - 1]
        current_position = key_positions[current_key]
        previous_position = key_positions[previous_key]
        total_time += abs(current_position - previous_position)

    return total_time

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(input().strip())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the keyboard layout
    keyboard = input().strip()
    # Read the word to type
    word = input().strip()
    # Calculate and print the typing time
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    """
    Calculate the time required to type a given word on a specific keyboard layout.

    Args:
        keyboard (str): A string representing the keyboard layout where each character is a unique lowercase Latin letter.
        word (str): The word to be typed, consisting of lowercase Latin letters.

    Returns:
        int: The total time required to type the word.
    """
    # Create a dictionary to map each key to its position on the keyboard
    key_positions = {}
    for index, key in enumerate(keyboard):
        key_positions[key] = index

    # Initialize the total time to 0
    total_time = 0

    # Calculate the time for each consecutive letter in the word
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        time_to_move = abs(key_positions[word[i]] - key_positions[word[i - 1]])
        total_time += time_to_move

    return total_time

# Example usage
if __name__ == "__main__":
    keyboard = input()
    word = input()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)

requirement analysis:
The primary requirement is to calculate the time required to type a given word on a specific keyboard layout. The keyboard layout is provided as a string of 26 lowercase Latin letters, and the word to be typed is given with a maximum length of 10^5 characters. The challenge lies in optimizing the performance for large input words. The program should be able to handle multiple test cases efficiently.

- Allow user customization of keyboard layouts for personalized typing experiences.
- Implement a feature to track and display typing speed improvements over time.

The script will first map each key to its position on the keyboard, then calculate the time taken to type each letter in the word based on the positions of the keys. The time for each letter will be the absolute difference between the positions of the current and previous keys.

examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

The first line of a description contains a keyboard — a string of length 26, which consists only of lowercase Latin letters. Each of the letters from 'a' to 'z' appears exactly once on the keyboard.

The second line of the description contains the word s. The word has a length from 1 to 50 letters inclusive and consists of lowercase Latin letters.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case is the minimal time it takes to type the word s on the given keyboard.

Example

Input


5
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
hello
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
i
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
codeforces
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
qqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqq
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
abacaba


Output


13
0
68
0
74
